awd_abstract_narration:
Crystal defects such as grain boundaries, cracks, or dislocations play significant roles in determining material properties and behaviors. To efficiently and reliably predict failure phenomena, fundamental level of descriptions at nanoscales are widely used to study how defects affect macroscopic properties such as elasticity and plasticity. Challenged by the computational limitations as well as high-fidelity requirements, this research project aims to develop and employ multiscale methods which can retain accuracy around defect cores while improving efficiency through local continuum descriptions. Two popular multiscale modeling strategies are: (1) bottom-up: coarse-graining of microscopic descriptions (e.g., atomistic models) of material behavior; (2) top-down: informing macroscopic models (e.g., continuum equations) with physics gleaned from the microscopic scales. The former provides "a closer" comparison with macroscopic experiments and the latter predicts the materials microscopic properties. This project focuses on several aspects of the multiscale modeling and mathematical analysis for both bottom-up and top-down approaches, aims at developing efficient and reliable coupling methods which smoothly integrate the microscopic and macroscopic descriptions, and establishing rigorous error estimates that will set precise guidelines for practical implementation (e.g., the optimal parameters used in the coupling mechanism and the finite element mesh used in the macroscopic scale). This project will also provide an opportunity to train both graduate and undergraduate students in the context of challenging and interdisciplinary research among applied mathematics, materials science and mechanical engineering.

The overarching goal of this project is to develop multiscale methods for both bottom-up and top-down approaches with provable performance in terms of accuracy, efficiency, and reliability based on theoretical analysis and comprehensive error estimates. In particular, these are the four objectives: (1) The research will promote the understanding of bottom-up atomistic-to-continuum (AtC) methods for complex structured crystals. Successful outcomes of this project will greatly extend the applicability of existing AtC methods from simple lattice crystals to more complex ones. The comprehensive error analysis will lead to optimal coupling strategy and provide precise guidelines for practical implementations. (2) The research will also advance the developments of top-down nonlocal-to-local (NtL) continuum couplings. The new coupling framework is built based on geometric reconstruction, and will remove interfacial inconsistency while maintain all physical properties globally, such as conservation of energy and balance of linear momentum, in multi-dimensions, whereas none of existing coupling methods for NtL problems satisfies all of these properties. Furthermore, mathematical analysis will be built to ensure the well-posedness and reliability of modeling and computations. (3) This project will enhance the understandings and interconnections between the top-down and bottom-up approaches, and will also facilitate the exploitation of other scale-bridging algorithms in materials science. (4) High order and robust numerical schemes for large-scale problems will be developed to enhance the controls and designs of defects inside complex structured crystals, and improve the prediction of materials failures.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to develop and analyze new multiscale modeling and reliable numerical schemes in materials science. The research component of this project is integrated very well with the educational goal, by introducing the new knowledge into studnent courses, providing graduate and undergraduate research training, and organizing annual local Math Symposium to strengthen communication and collaboration and to help promoting the minority researchers in various disciplines. 

For the intellectual merits, the PI developed multiscale methods for both bottom-up and top-down approaches with provable performance. The outcomes can be categorized into three inter-related parts: (1) the development of new multiscale models for defective materials; (2) the development of robust numerical simulators and numerical analysis; (3) the understandings and interconnections of other scale-bridging algorithms in materials science. 

On the modeling side, one bottom-up coupling model and one top-down coupling model have been developed.

The PI and her collaborators used the bottom-up approach to formulate the blended force-based quasi-continuum (BQCF) method for multi-lattices with point and line defects, and developed rigorous analysis to provide optimal implementation “parameters": choice of atomistic region, blending region, and continuum finite element mesh.

The PI and her collaborators used the top-down approach to develop a new consistent multiscale method to link a nonlocal diffusion model directly with the classical local diffusion in one dimensional space. This new coupling framework removes interfacial inconsistency, ensures the flux balance, and satisfies energy conservation as well as the maximum principle, whereas none of existing coupling methods for nonlocal-to-local coupling satisfies all these properties.

On the numerical side, new numerical schemes and numerical analyses were developed for these novel multiscale models.

The PI developed the novel numerical scheme for the blended force-based quasi-continuum (BQCF) coping method, established rigorous error estimates that set precise guidelines for practical implementation. The new numerical scheme improved computational accuracy and efficiency in modeling complex structures, and fracture propagation of brittle solids.

The PI also developed a new scheme to discretize the coupling operator for the nonlocal-to-local problem. This new first order finite difference approximation preserved the flux and the maximum principle on a discrete level. In addition, this new scheme provided a remedy to resolve the numerical boundary artifacts of nonlocal problem where a classical local boundary condition is used, together with a coupled fully nonlocal model in the interior of the domain.

For the broader impacts, this project brought benefits to materials science, mathematics, education and research dissemination. 

In materials science: The proposed bottom-up and top-down coupling models and the associated numerical solvers improved accuracy and efficiency in simulating defective crystals. The new coupling models also greatly extended the scope of existing methods which are mostly limited to simple lattice crystals to incorporate more complex ones. 

In mathematics:  Firstly, new theoretical analysis and methodologies were developed for the exploration of these proposed models. Secondly, this project provided comprehensive numerical analysis for these schemes and quantified the stability conditions for implementation of various applications. Thirdly, this project also enhanced the understandings and interconnections between the top-down and bottom-up approaches and facilitated the exploitation of other scale-bridging algorithms in materials science. For example, the PI and collaborators completed the review paper of the Local-to-Nonlocal (LtN) coupling methods. This review paper discussed the connections among various coupling strategies and provided an overview of the state-of-the-art of LtN coupling in the context of nonlocal diffusion and nonlocal mechanics. 

In education: This project has partially supported one female PhD student, Dan Han from 2017-2019. After graduation, Dr Han became an assistant professor of department of mathematics at University of Louisville. This project has supported 10 undergraduates in summer research experience program since 2017. One undergraduate student became a full-time mathematics teacher in a K-12 high school in North Carolina; two of them will seek PhD degrees in STEM majors. This project has also supported 2 master students in research experience program and their master thesis. Both master students became PhD students in STEM majors. This project has supported the annual Oct Math Day symposium in 2020 and 2021, which strengthen the communication and collaboration of mathematical researchers, and provide a networking opportunity for students and faculty with our alumni. In addition, the symposiums help promoting the minority researchers in various disciplines. 

In research dissemination: The PI gives 23 conference, seminars and poster presentations about developed results in the applied mathematics, computational mechanics, and material science communities. The PI taught the advanced seminar course in multiscale modeling for materials science at UNC Charlotte. The resultant numerical solvers from this project are opensource software, which were uploaded and updated on PI’s website https://sites.google.com/site/xingjiehelenli/

for public use. With the support this project, three peer-reviewed journal papers have been published, one SIAM article has been published with author being undergraduate; one journal paper has been accepted and one journal paper has been submitted.
